comments.commentBody:
@Magoo: I have submitted pix of myself in some college apps but that was years ago and I understand it is no longer required. If I didn't want to submit my pic in a swimsuit and a college required it, I'd go somewhere else.

Why do opponents of pageants continue to ignore the fact that these women CHOOSE to do this? No one is making them do it. Why is this particular CHOICE bringing such a negative reaction?

Feminists s/b SUPPORTING a woman's right to choose, remember?

Fred, a feminist does not consider "choice" to be the single defining characteristic of what is good for girls, women, or any single person. You are very much mistaken if you think Feminism = anarchy.

Similarly, civil rights law recognizes that you cannot set out whatever collection of parameters you wish when it comes to hiring for work, education, and so on. Some parameters are irrelevant or simply capriciously discriminatory for no good reason. In this case, they are illegal.

I would argue that Miss America should stop calling itself a scholarship contest when the parameters it sets out for winning include decidedly non-scholarly criteria. It should call itself a female beauty and poise contest, if it cares about honesty. And then you can have a discussion about why our culture thinks both are important for women worthy of televising.

It's actually very hard to find many "unattractive" women on television, even in news where presumably brains are what matters. In contrast, you can't throw a stone at a bunch of male pundits or TV experts without hitting a splotchy, wobbly, jiggley, hairy-yet-bald man. Seems like for them, "character" is what really matters for getting the job. Hm.
Can you explain how beauty contests contribute to transcending  cultural stereotypes and empowering young women? I genuinely wish to know.

Congratulations, Ms. Redd, on transcending cultural stereotypes and empowering and inspiring so many young women.  It occurs to me that middle-aged and older women would benefit from a book like your Body Drama. Sadly, women over 40 are frequently overlooked in U.S. society, a situation that needs to be changed.

My grandmother was abandoned by her mother at age 5 (mom was divorced and destitute) so my gma was sent to KS to work on a farm - rehoming by a birth mom without the internet.   At age 5 she was treated as a farm hand and likely worse, left that family at age 15, married as quickly as she could find someone and was thrice divorced.  My gma would not talk about her childhood but what I know now from studying the impact of early trauma and attachment challenges, I realize how many of my gma's behaviors, and especially the cold, detached way she treated my mother, stemmed from that early maltreatment.  My grandmother was the only person in our family who questioned our decision to adopt internationally -- she asked me "why would you want to raise someone else's throwaway kid?"  Sadly, that's the way she felt about herself- I wouldn't call that doing well.
And we have Graham, McCain, and Obama to thank for that.  But not too many others. . . .

Seems to me this entire episode leaves people opining about Obama's assets or incompetence based on their preexisting bias about him. I don't think people realize how important bias is. Also, they have images or notions about how leadership is supposed to look that seem to be based on movies more than reality. All that matters is we've used the oldest strategy in the world - the credible threat of military action to force a diplomatic solution. At least for the time being. That solution may evaporate. But I would suggest keeping the threat on the table to force Assad and Putin to take action.

much of the american population denies the age of the universe as being measured in billions of years, they're stuck on six thousand or so. not some small fringe of fanatics, polls state figures like forty percent of americans, of course higher in republicans, believe such nonsense. yet they daily use technologies directly derived from our space missions. the list of technologies developed from NASA's blasts into space are too lengthy to post, given the word limit. if the average american understood the return on investment gained by the space program and basic science research in genral, they'd demand that their elected politicians increase spending for such endeavors exponentially. alas, the average american ain't too bright.
i  have to say, a waiter or bartender seems more respectable than a wall street banker.

When will Dr. Krugman see the light and admit the obvious fact that corporate "free trade" is destroying our middle and working class economy in order to further enrich the already obscenely rich plutocrats. We've lost millions of jobs and at least tens of thousands of industries to the mirage of "comparative advantage." The plutocrats aren't letting up on their relentless assault on everything we thought our country stood for. The Trans Pacific Partnership Treaty is currently being negotiated in a shroud of secrecy, so that it can be sprung on us as "fast track" legislation. The TPP will not only continue the strip mining of our economy it also cedes a significant amount of our national sovereignty to those bloodless artificial "persons" a/k/a multinational corporations. The TPP will empower these entities to sue our government for damages if the enforcement of our laws on such things as environmental protection and workplace safety cost them money. The treaty thoughtfully creates a private court system for such suits, with judges taken from the legions of white shoe corporate lawyers. We'd better start preparing our kids for lives as waitresses, bartenders and WalMart greeters.

A good article describes actions taken by the government that provide the structure for inequality.

http://www.cepr.net/index.php/blogs/beat-the-press/government-policy-gav...

The top 15-20% made a ton, too. Just not as obscene an amount as the top one percent.

There is no, "we 99%."

In the years after the 2008 downturn, the economy 'reportedly' ceased being in a recession by June 2009. As such, each consecutive quarter after June 2009 has been declared to have 'expanded', no matter how small.

However, people openly deride the idea of a 'recovery.' If we are in a 'recovery' as they declared, why haven't we had the benefit of experiencing such a empirical condition? The answer is simple; because it never reached us- we, the 99% have been subject to the whims of a slowly 'recovering' economy, with no foreseen end in sight.

But, that leaves out the 1%, who aren't lumped with us; what is happening to them? Given the so called non existent recovery, what is happening to them?

Filling the hole from PK's article, we can surmise 2 ideas; 1) that the recovery is a hoax, or 2) that the recovery has happened, but its hasn't reached us yet. Given that we're the crowd that doesn't doubt math in general, Option 2 is the most likely.

The 1% has a monopoly on the profits of the growth in the economy occurring. That is a fact. They have had the benefit of a 'recovering' economy; we have not.

Which calls another idea to question; trickle down theory. Trickle down theory assured us that, if they, the 1%, prospered, we'd, the 99%, would follow suit. It has and will likely never happen forever.

The 1% has grown; we haven't.

It is a debunked theory.

This enduring disaster/veiled class warfare must stop. We must retake recovery for ourselves and cure our ills.

If America had taken the good Professor's advice instead of the voodoo economics pablum of the Neo-Con-Artists, the national debt would be half of today's debt because adult taxation levels would have prevented the catastrophic treasury bleeding from George W. Bush's tax cuts for the wealthy.

Higher taxes generate more circulation of money, which is the lifeblood of any economy.

In addition, Krugman's advocacy of Keynesian stimulus advice would have also improved the American and global economies if it had been heeded by the Randian-Austerian Mellonites driving us over cliffs.

Northern Europe and Canada all have high-tax, high-performing economies with broad public services to serve the masses.

I'm certain the Professor would happily hand over higher taxes on his income since he realizes he's a member of society, not a master or Robber Baron of society.

Krugman is the solution.

Right-wing trickle-down poverty is the problem.

If that Sum is the correct formula, then in other words it's the sum of ((1/2)sin(2θ))^n for 0 <= n < oo. This is a geometric series, so the sum is

sum = 1 / (1 - (1/2)sin(2θ)) = 2/(2 - sin(2θ)).

Since |(1/2)sin(2θ)| < 1 no matter what θ is, this sum is valid for any θ.

But as θ approaches 0, the sum approaches 1 (not oo). The largest the sum can ever get is 2 (when sin(2θ) = 1). The smallest it can be is 2/3 (when sin(2θ) = -1).

Proficiency in the use of a pocket calculator is not a requirement for members of Congress. Nor is common sense.

Some day, maybe...
Reality is not on the Republican agenda.

“Obamacare is the most dangerous piece of legislation ever passed in Congress,” said Representative John Fleming, Republican of Louisiana. “It is the most existential threat to our economy” that the country has seen “since the Great Depression, so I think a little bit of additional deficit is nothing,” he added."       The non-partisan CBO says that Obamacare will save money

OMG, I laughed so hard I woke up sleeping spouse.
I was once chased by Jon Sebastian's (in my memory) really scary dog while skating on a pond. These celebrity encounters do stay with you. Great story.
Our foremost problem is the Republican Party, which has taken leave of reality.

I think the speaker of the house and his congressional colleagues should put the interest of the country over the usual medieval like party politics. President Obama no longer runs for re-election, the Supreme Court has uphold the healthcare as the law of the land and Americans are sick and tired of the childish like behavior of the lawmakers – especially the Republicans.
Knowing the state of the economy and the global challenges the United States is facing congress has to make genuine behavioral changes in its approaches the budget issue. Speaker Boehner’s main challenge in crafting time fitting federal budget emanates from his own party not from the other side. And if part of the House Republicans are not persuaded to stop their outdated tactics to stop or delay the healthcare law, not only the US economy will slow but also the budget deficit increases.
The foremost problem the United States has at this very time is not the civil war in Syria or competing against the Europeans, Chinese, or the Russian but overcoming the incompetence of one branch of the government in dispensing its responsibility.

It is what it is.  Why mask for something it's not.  When some air headed gal with a hard body and understanding of Christianity that is so limited that she tatts herself out and everyone coos over the expression individualism it represents, it isn't even close to representing valid components of success, unless flim flam is what passes for success now.  I guess it does, so it's right on.  Let's face it, though, it's largely a bully pulpit for launching an acting, p.r., or modeling career and it's all about the look, make no mistake. I'm fine with all of that, what I'm not is couching it in some kind of terms of scholarship and real well rounded intelligence, which is by accident at best in this context.

Congratulations on your successful experience as Miss America.  I have mixed feelings about the pageant: the swimsuit competition gives me pause, but the pageant otherwise encourages poise, communications skills, ability to present publicly and education, all worthwhile components of success.

Right, 5:30, no problem with LETT today.

Thanks for the verbal recco yesterday, I appreciate it.
Wrong reply box, not my new nickname for Martin

Got to pre-preveal tonight, as I'm off for a while.  I thought of him too when I did the puzzle.  He removed such a fear from our lives.  I remember vividly the news bulletin, the first one in my young life, which had everybody riveted.  I fear the mind meld is complete.

It was NOT easy, Bru.

It took me 2% longer than last Friday's.

I'm erratic with stats. I don't keep track of my best times for given days of the week except Mondays, but my best Friday time that I made a note of was a P. Berry. Just on "Play Against The Clock" alone, 80 people were faster than me that Fri.
Most of those people think they are ethical.  An ethics course would do and does do little.

Harvard Business School probably does include a mandatory "Ethics" course.  Far more effective to require them to live on Fast Food wages for a Semester, no help from your family allowed.  Or just dump them out at a local homeless shelter $20 in their pockets and tell them to survive for a week, no ID, cash cards or calls home allowed.  The lives of even the non-elite students live are so far from those of ordinary Americans as to defy comprehension.

Michael Sandel is one of Harvard's best-known current philosophy professors and the author of "What Money Can Buy..."

They should make him dean of the business school... :-P

PS: the book is great!

I have the general impression that the top 1% is dominated by people in what I consider to be non-productive pursuits. They don't really make or produce anything useful. Referring of course to the financial world where money is used to make money through financial manipulation. Pump and dump financial experts. Leveraged buyouts, exchange traded funds, exotic financial instruments, fund advisers that constantly churn portfolios etc. etc.

Too late now, but the US would be far better off right now if Harvard Business School had included "Ethics" in its curriculum long ago - rather than as a recent addition.

Pivotal for the Grey Lady to provide the forum for the conversation which is our most productive existential tool.
I welcome todo el mundo to share their best ideas. This forum, mediated, is highly elevated, with interesting and diverse proposals to improve results.
Most appreciative of your contributions. Promising that everybody's talking.
Appeals to reason trend minimal where interest exists.
Carry on.

Have you ever wondered what the "Tea Party" is all about? Have you noticed where it's base is located? Have you ever wondered why the facts are so twisted and the language so toxic? Have you noticed that the president is black?

It is these stateless groups, independent and proxies, that are the muddle in Syria, as targets and objects of blame. But globally, they show up in important places. In Bangladesh, western corporations are claiming membership in stateless standards group, funded by corporate dollars whose inspections are subcontracted without review, exempts them from investing in standards and improving oversight.

In Ghana, Chinese groups from local China communities have been forced to forfeit millions in small gold mining claims and many Chinese have been detained in Ghana, in a state-local-international conflict.

In America and Europe, xenophobic tensions are expressed as competition for jobs, and non-resident workers are socially and politically set upon. We are all familiar with the issues of blood diamonds. The drug cartels are international, and stateless.

Temp agencies, in a sense, have replaced unions. They organize workers who are sheared of benefits, advancement opportunities, grievance rights and directed by a daily ticket.

The reach of multinational corporations is well known.

Legally established or not, taken in total, these stateless operations cross borders, enter into economies, affect workers, and transfer wealth in ways and amounts only recently inconceivable.

Whether through terror or tragedy, or legal oppression (cited as the prevailing wage), their disruption and destruction will widen the chasm between rich and poor--even as wealth increases.
You've summed up exactly what I am afraid of for our country.

"the only good democracy is one they can buy" - brilliant phrase, did you coin that?  But, come, let's not be so pessimistic!  After all, we did in our history overthrow the rule of a monarch and put an end to the worst example of exploitation by the wealthy in modern history, plantation slavery - at a huge cost in blood and anguish.
I suspect that at some point the top .01% will overreach, at which time they will regret their GOP minions did such a great job of arming the general populace...

This disintegration of our democracy into an oligarchy is no accident. It is the spoils of class warfare, waged by the wealthy against everyone else as it always has been, but in deadly earnest since the 1970s. That's when working-class wages stagnated under the assault on labor, when middle-class women flooded into the job market seeking to buttress an increasingly unaffordable lifestyle (that is, home, health and education), and the rich began raking in the tax breaks and all the other perks of power, including the purchase of Congress, the presidency and the courts - and the news media.

Now the Republican candidate for mayor of New York is accusing the Democrat de Blasio of class warfare. Typical effrontery of the wealthy and Republicans - accuse others of doing what you're doing yourself. These people don't like democracy and never have. For them, the only good democracy is one they can buy.

And they have. I see no way out, and I see this country continuing to decline into political totalitarianism, economic decrepitude and moral irrelevancy.

Mouse, sorry to disagree, but what you say is at variance with the scientific understanding. Much of this information comes from surveys and interviews, but male and female sexual responses can also be measured more directly, e.g., with penile or vaginal plethysmography. Men and women don't respond equally to the same stimuli, which isn't surprising, since no sexually-reproducing species of which I'm aware has that kind of symmetry.

TomP, I think that if you're talking about marketing, you're going to find exploitation -- it isn't exactly a respectable profession..That being said, I don't think most of us get hot and bothered about efforts to exploit our male sexual urges. Just look at those cable shows that have a scene that shows breasts every week.

It is known that women seeking mates respond strongly to signs of material success. There's a good evolutionary reason for this, namely, it's correlated with ability to provide for the child.

I'm beginning to think that not everyone in this conversation is familiar with the research on sexual attraction in the human male and female.

Josh Hill, you said:
"I'm beginning to think that not everyone in this conversation is familiar with the research on sexual attraction in the human male and female."

Perhaps, or perhaps some of us don't think a biological argument is valid when debating the worth of a beauty contest. We get that men are visual but that doesn't matter when applied to a "civilized" society, as we are expected to keep our inhibitions in check.

Miss America and other beauty pageants are largely irrelevant as few people pay attention to them but they can't be completely ignored as they do propagate sexist notions.

What nonsense. No one forces these women to compete in these contests. since when does this author think she should have the power to tell people they can not show off for the public.

If people are willing to pay to see them for their physical looks, that is for those who do so. If what some see as an ideal and are willing to reward someone for appearing like that ideal, is just fine.

Chelsea Rick does not have to parade around in bikinis and high heels, no one is forcing her to do so. So she is fortunate to have a great physical appeal to many, well if she can capitalize on it, good for her.
If i was younger, single, and lot richer I might even make an effort to meet her.
She might not be an emotional match, but it would be fun trying to find out.
Could be Garry Owens.
The hints gave it away. I would have had no idea. And for once I even figured out the connection to the puzzle.
John, with so many remarriages and melded families nowadays, more and more people have a STETSON.
I'm fairly certain that Charles wears a STETSON.

Precisely why I picked him, Martin.

And the puzzle is as smooth as a Stetson. I own one. Everyone should own one.

We have a moderate party, known as the Democrats: by every measure known to political science, Barack Obama is slightly to the right of Dwight D. Eisenhower.  America's only salvation is to send the nullificationist Republicans packing.

Hail and amen, Garrett:  We did not elect Obama to be Professor in Chief - we elected him to be President. As I listen to him these days, I cannot help but wonder whether anything at all raises his ire.  His communication ability has degraded to the point that it is infuriating to those of us who are outraged at the nihilist, ignorant Tea Party thugs, and the inability of the paralyzed Republicans to control their spawn. We don't need Obama's dreary and measured recitations of the complexities of things - we need a bare knuckle brawler like LBJ to ram things through Congress, at which he was spectacularly good.  He should call the Republicans out - not endlessly try to placate them, which will never happen.  I fear that we will all be sold down the river if this tide doesn't turn.
